title: What we can do or what Riot can do to players refuse to play the Autofilled role ?
body:
The autofill function is actually quite fair since everyone will eventually get support after a couple of games.

This morning in the champion selection, someone got support role and he refused to be support, instead, he firstly asked for adc and then asked for top lane. After no one would swap with him, he turned to be very crazy, and picked jax support with {{summoner:13}} and{{summoner:1}} 

In the game, he did nothing in the lane and made our adc Lucian afk after 5 minutes.

What we can do to make this player get his punishment? The behaviour is awful and basically made everyone upset

replies.body:
> What can we do?

Quite simply, ignore their behaviour in-game and report in the post game. These kinds of players are looking for a reaction and by giving them a hard time for doing what they do you're basically just encouraging them. The best thing to do is ignore them, play the game to the best of your abilities and report them in the post-game to notify Riot of their behaviour.

> What can Riot do?

Quite simply, punish them. As long as Riot are receiving reports about these kinds of players, they can assess the situation(s) and dish out punishments to deserving players. It *might* not happen for the match you report them, but it will happen should they continue with their negative behaviour.

"Quite simply, punish them. As long as Riot are receiving reports about these kinds of players, they can assess the situation(s) and dish out punishments to deserving players. It might not happen for the match you report them, but it will happen should they continue with their negative behaviour."

I know it's a hard role for anyone to get used to, but support should never seem as a "punishable" role.

Rito has been over the last month or so, trying to push support into a more enjoyable and universally playable role for everyone, but it may be too little too late.

I've been a support main for over 4 years now, and I love the role. Not because I do "tons of damage" or get any sort of "killing spree", but because I can be the little bird in the shadows doing my work, and when pulling off a "save" or an "outplay" really well, it surprises my team and I get something better than text on my screen; I get team recognition, and usually a new friend (the adc most times).

I'm not saying its a role for everyone, but you can learn A LOT of skills and knowledge of others, being free from focusing too hard on cs and trying to do maximum damage to your enemies. You have the opportunity to learn how to read your map, become more aware of your situational environment, learn your enemies movement patterns and your adc's, and learn how to get your team in and out of fights with minimal loss.
You wont pick these skills up straight away, but it's worth having support as your 2nd or 3rd preferred role just to build up these skills.

> I know it's a hard role for anyone to get used to, but support should never seem as a "punishable" role.

It's not about "making support a punishable role", it's about "refusing to participate in play" being punishable. From what has been said in the OP, the player in question was refusing to assist their team by not actually doing anything, which is a punishable offence.
